message_1: A radioactive substance with an initial mass of 50 grams has a half-life of 10 years. How much of the substance will remain after 40 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 50 grams, the half-life is 10 years, and the time elapsed is 40 years. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 50 * (1/2)^(40 / 10)

Final mass = 50 * (1/2)^4

Final mass = 50 * (1/16)

Final mass = 50 * 0.0625

Final mass = 3.125 grams

So, after 40 years, 3.125 grams of the radioactive substance will remain.
